instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ADAPTER_EN: What is ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.C1802: What is C1802? Capacitor to ground on PCH_SRTCRST_L on machines from 2009-2012, PCH_SRTCRST_L needs to be high for PCH to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
threads.message:
I have a 2012 13" MacBook Pro
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
Using genuine 85W charger.

Green Light

Rails prior are there and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.56V

​​​​​​​Get to <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS_FET</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>) and I measure 0.059V
I measure pins 1 and 2 on <RESISTOR>R7842</RESISTOR> and I get 4.98 and 4.86 respectively.
I decided to check <SIGNAL>P5_3V3_SUS_EN</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>PM_SUS_EN</SIGNAL>) at pin 4 on <CHIP>U7940</CHIP> and I get 0v

This is where I get lost and start to feel like I am chasing my tail.

Any help or "hints" would be great. NO liquid damage whatsoever to this board. It is the cleanest I have ever seen and upon disassembly, I can tell no one has ever been inside this machine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
threads.message: I'll remeasure when I get back home from my real job (boo.) I'm sure I measured last night and I am sure the _L added to my confusion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
threads.message: No SUS from PCH, the worst. Check voltages on RTC circuit <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>/01, <CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/03. <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> @ <RESISTOR>R5085</RESISTOR> PIN1 I have 0V.

<RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>/01 both measure 3.3V (with appropriate drop through resistors)
<CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/03 Both measure 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
threads.message: You sure this adapter is OK?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
threads.message:
It is brand new from Apple. I just bought it this week. 85w magsafe 1
Other boards and computers work just fine off to it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
threads.message: I fail to see why <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> would matter if <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is not there. Tried powering it up with a charged battery connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
threads.message: Yes, known good battery with at least a 50% charge, using pads, still won't turn on...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
threads.message: <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> present with charged battery+AC? It needs to be there, else SMC suspect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
threads.message:
I will check it out with a battery connected and charger connected when I get back home.

I've never replaced an SMC, but pretty much have every other IC on the boards. If I had a working SMC (balled of course) it should fix the issue? Not sure if it is worth my time. I guess it would be a good test/experiment for my 1st SMC replacement...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
threads.message: <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is almost always SMC issue. Could be crap under it, so flux and heat first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, no power/fan
threads.message:
Sounds good. I'll flux and heat it up (not to reflow, just to get the crap out)

I should remove the clear edge bonding, correct, even just for trying to clean under the chip?

I'll report back. hopefully with good news.
